Let $M$ be a set. The Cartesian product of $M$ with itself, denoted as $M \times M$, is the set of all ordered pairs of elements from $M$.
A subgroup $H \subset G$ is called a normal subgroup of $G$ if $aH = Ha$ for all $a \in G$, i.e., if for each element $a \in G$ the associated left and right cosets of $H$ in $G$ coincide.
For a ring R, the set of multiplicatively invertible elements is denoted by R*. These elements are called the units of R.
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the intersection $\mathfrak{a} \cap \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{x ; x \in \mathfrak{a} \text { and } x \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.

Let $R$ be a ring and $\mathfrak{a}$ an ideal in $R$. The factor ring, or residue class ring, $R / \mathfrak{a}$, is defined initially as an abelian group by viewing $\mathfrak{a}$ as a (normal) subgroup of the additive group of $R$. The elements of $R / \mathfrak{a}$ are all residue classes of type $x+\mathfrak{a}$ for $x \in R$, where addition is given by $(x+\mathfrak{a})+(y+\mathfrak{a})=(x+y)+\mathfrak{a}$ and multiplication by $(x+\mathfrak{a}) \cdot(y+\mathfrak{a})=(x \cdot y)+\mathfrak{a}$. The ring properties of $R$ carry over to $R / \mathfrak{a}$.

An element $p$ in a unique factorization domain $R$ is called a prime element if it generates a prime ideal, i.e., the ideal $(p)$ is such that if $p$ divides a product of elements in $R$, then $p$ divides at least one of those elements.
The length l_A(M) of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers l such that there is a chain of submodules 0 subsetneq M_1 subsetneq M_2 subsetneq ... subsetneq M_l = M of length l.
The extension field $L$ is called algebraic over $K$ if every element $\alpha \in L$ is algebraic over $K$.

A normal field extension is an extension field that is the splitting field of a family of polynomials from the base field. It is a prestage to Galois extensions. An algebraic field extension \\(K \subset L\\) is called normal if it satisfies the equivalent conditions of Theorem 4: (i) Every \\(K\\)-homomorphism \\(L \longrightarrow \bar{L}\\) into an algebraic closure \\(\bar{L}\\) of \\(L\\) restricts to an automorphism of \\(L\\). (ii) \\(L\\) is a splitting field of a family of polynomials in \\(K[X]\\). (iii) Every irreducible polynomial in \\(K[X]\\) that admits a zero in \\(L\\) decomposes over \\(L\\) completely into linear factors.
An extension $L / K$ is called separable if it does not contain any inseparable algebraic elements over $K$.

A permutation $\pi \in \mathfrak{S}_{n}$ is called a cycle if there exist distinct elements $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}$ in $\{1, \ldots, n\}, r \geq 2$, such that $\pi(x_{i}) = x_{i+1}$ for $1 \leq i < r$, $\pi(x_{r}) = x_{1}$, and $\pi(x) = x$ for $x \in \{1, \ldots, n\} - \{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$.
The codomain of a function is the set that contains all potential output values, even if some of those values are not actually produced by any input in the domain.

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: The definition of a normal subgroup involves the concept of cosets, which are essentially Cartesian products of the subgroup with the group elements.
The definition of a factor ring involves viewing an ideal as a normal subgroup of the additive group of the ring.
The definition of a factor ring involves the concept of ideals, as it is constructed using an ideal in the ring.
The definition of a prime element involves the concept of prime ideals, which are a specific type of ideal.
A normal field extension is a specific type of algebraic field extension, and its definition relies on the concept of algebraic field extensions.
A separable extension is a specific type of algebraic field extension, and its definition relies on the concept of algebraic field extensions.
